title: (x) UPS corporate typeface - UPS Sans (FF Dax rip-off) {George}
content:
I am doing some work for The UPS Store and am really liking their font "UPS Sans".

I wouldn't want to use UPS Sans on another project so can anyone tell me what typeface it is based on.

Let me know if you need more of a sample.

Thank you.

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [UPS\_Sans.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20150130165201/http:/typophile.com/files/UPS_Sans.jpg) | 196.67 KB |
author: Guerella

comments.content: [FutureBrand](http://web.archive.org/web/20150130165201/http:/typophile.com/wiki/FutureBrand) did the UPS rebranding a couple of years ago. Featured on their site is the casestudy claiming that " a custom typeface was develloped", when in fact, even here on Typophile, a lot of us noticed that it is merely, if at all, an adaptation of the ubiquous FF Dax. So I guess it is safe to suggest you use this typeface if you can't get the "UPS Sans" corporate typeface.

This is a VERY sore subject. Dax is the face you would want to use, not UPS's "Corporate" jolly roger font.  
 [http://www.fontshop.com/?fuseaction=catalog.fontpackage&searchby=manufac...](http://web.archive.org/web/20150130165201/http:/www.fontshop.com/?fuseaction=catalog.fontpackage&searchby=manufacturer&displayfontid=FF.10269.0.0 "http://www.fontshop.com/?fuseaction=catalog.fontpackage&searchby=manufacturer&displayfontid=FF.10269.0.0")

ChrisL

It looks like a customized Dax  
Edit: Oops... to late!

It _is_ reverse-engineered FF Dax. Erik Spiekermann showed us proof at TypeCon2005, and I had already come to that same conclusion through my research for my presentation about piracy issues in corporate typeface design.
